I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based loan to the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI) for subprogram 2 of the Public 
Sector Program.1 
 
2.  The  program,  supported  by  a  policy-based  loan,  will  improve  the  long-term  fiscal 
sustainability of the Government of the Marshall Islands. In 2010, the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) approved (i) a program cluster for the public sector program and (ii) financing from the 
Asian Development Fund (ADF) of $9.5 million (SDR6,413,000) for subprogram 1 of the public 
sector program.2 The public sector program supports the implementation of the government’s 
reform initiatives and initiates the adjustments required to achieve long-term fiscal sustainability. 
Under subprogram 1, policy actions were designed and the implementation of immediate reform 
priorities began. Subprogram 2 will complete the implementation of the policy actions. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The RMI consists of 29 low-lying atolls and five single islands that cover 181 square 
kilometers of land area spread across nearly 5 million square kilometers of the western Pacific 
Ocean. The country gained independence in 1979, having been administered by the United 
States (US) as part of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands since 1947. The 2011 census 
recorded a total population of 53,158 persons, with approximately 74% of the population living 
on Majuro and Ebeye.3 ADB has identified the RMI as a fragile situation since 2008; among the 
constraints that underlie weak performance and fragility are weak public sector institutions, 
limited government capacity, and underdeveloped governance systems.4 
 
4.  The RMI economy relies heavily on government expenditure and, in turn, on foreign 
grants, which fund more than two-thirds of government expenditure. Most foreign grants are 
provided  by  the  US, mainly  under  the  amended  Compact  of  Free  Association.5 Increased 
foreign grants helped the economy grow at an average annual rate of 3.1% in FY2000–FY2007. 
However, the economy contracted by 1.9% in FY2008 and 1.3% in FY2009, as high world food 
and  fuel  prices  raised  inflation  to  14.7%,  prompting  the  declaration  of  a  state  of  national 
economic emergency. The economy grew by 5.2% in FY2010, driven by an expansion of fishery 
output and exports, and moderating fuel prices. Similarly, growth in FY2011 was 5.0%, driven 
by bigger fish catches, large inflows from the Kwajalein land use agreement, and the Federal 
Aviation Administration-funded airport extension project (Table 1).

5.  Growth over the medium term in the RMI is expected to stay low at around 1.5%,6 and 
revenues are projected to decline (Table 2). Within this low-growth scenario, the RMI needs to 
adjust  to  the  annual  decline  in  US  Compact  grants,  which  will  expire  in  FY2023.  Of  a 
$130 million annual budget in FY2011, about $95 million was funded by bilateral donors, with 
approximately two-thirds of this representing Compact grants. The RMI and US governments 
are investing in a Compact trust fund that is intended to generate a revenue stream to replace 
Compact  grants  from  FY2024.  Contributions  from  the  RMI  government  have  fallen  short, 
however, because excessive recurrent expenditure and poor revenue performance prevented 
the generation of the required fiscal surpluses. Under current policies, there will be insufficient 
government assets in the Compact trust fund in 2023 to replace the expiring Compact grants.7

6.  Fiscal  and  structural  reforms  are  therefore  urgently  needed  to  achieve  fiscal 
sustainability and generate sustainable medium-term economic growth. Structural reforms will 
stimulate private sector economic activity, generate domestic employment and incomes, and 
broaden the local tax base, while tax reforms will boost domestic revenue collection and offset 
the imminent reduction in grants. Implementing state-owned enterprise (SOE) reforms and 
reducing public expenditures will contribute to improving the fiscal balance. 
 
                                                
6  International Monetary Fund. 2011. Republic of the Marshall Islands. 2011 Article IV Consultation. Washington, DC.

3 
7.  In 2009, recognizing the need for reform, the RMI government began several initiatives 
to advance public sector reform and promote macroeconomic stability and sustainable growth. 
These included the preparation of a comprehensive recovery plan for the Marshalls Energy 
Company (MEC) and the formation of the Comprehensive Adjustment Program (CAP) Advisory 
Group and the Tax and Revenue Reform and Modernization (TRAM) Commission to prepare 
fiscal reform plans.8 These initiatives formed the basis of the government’s strategy to mitigate 
the impact of the global financial crisis and subsequently led to the design of ADB’s support for 
the public sector program (footnote 2). 
 
8.  Subprogram 1 supported the design and initial implementation of reforms to rectify the 
situation  in  which  the  government  found  itself  in  2008  and  2009.  The  subprogram  was 
implemented successfully by the government and had a positive outcome by putting in place a 
solid foundation on which to begin the implementation of further reforms under subprogram 2. 
Beginning in 2009, and continuing throughout the implementation of the program, the policy 
conditions of subprogram 1 have stabilized the fiscal situation, particularly in the areas of debt 
and expenditure management. 
 
9.  Under subprogram 1, the government onlent the majority of loan funds to MEC.9 The 
funds were used to repay a high-interest loan held by MEC with a commercial bank. Using the 
cash-flow savings from repaying this loan, MEC was able to refurbish a generator and achieve a 
significantly higher megawatt output, which reduced fuel usage by about 14%. 
 
10.  Subprogram 1 included several covenants concerning the rationalization of MEC, of 
which the onlending arrangement between the government and MEC was critical in contributing 
to MEC’s long-term commercial and financial stability.10 Under subprogram 1, the government 
was required to (i) ensure that a subsidiary loan agreement was executed between the Ministry 
of Finance (MOF) and MEC, (ii) establish a sinking fund account at a commercial bank to 
accumulate funds to service its repayment obligations under the loan agreement, (iii) ensure 
that MEC makes automatic monthly payments into the sinking fund account, and (iv) ensure that 
MOF had the first priority right to receive payments from other assets of MEC in the event of a 
default in the obligation of MEC to contribute to the sinking fund account. In addition, the loan 
agreement required MEC to (i) open a separate account at a commercial bank dedicated to 
repair and maintenance funds; and (ii) make automatic monthly payments into the repair and 
maintenance account from its revenue accounts, to be used exclusively for repair, maintenance, 
procurement of spare parts, materials, and equipment (and related labor costs) directly related 
to power generation and distribution. The government has complied with these covenants. 
 
11.  The program is aligned with the RMI country operations business plan (COBP), 2012–
2014 and ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2010–2014. It also applies lessons from earlier ADB policy 
programs in the RMI and elsewhere in the Pacific, as well as ADB’s approach to engaging with 
weakly  performing  countries,  notably  by  (i)  adopting  a  country-led  set  of  policy  actions 
developed in an open, participatory manner and at a pace in keeping with country practices, and 
(ii) initiating long-term policy dialogue and providing targeted technical assistance (TA).

B.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact will be that the public sector provides more efficient and effective services to 
the population. The outcome will be that the government achieves fiscal sustainability. For the 
purposes of the program, fiscal sustainability is defined as the Compact trust fund being on 
track to replace Compact grants in FY2024. 
 
C.  Outputs 
13.  Output 1: Government’s fiscal discipline improves over the medium term. Under 
subprogram 1, the cabinet endorsed budget targets for FY2011 and FY2012 to bring budget 
outcomes in line with International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommendations. The key target was 
a  budget  surplus  large  enough  to  fund  RMI  contributions  to  the  Compact  trust  fund. 
Complementary targets were set for other budget items, including civil servant wages and 
salaries, grants and transfers, capital expenditure, and tax revenue. The cabinet also endorsed 
debt management guidelines for the government and SOEs. 
 
14.  Under subprogram 2, these budget targets were to be implemented over FY2011 and 
FY2012, and fiscal restraint was to be maintained in the preparation of the budget for FY2013. 
To  improve  fiscal  discipline,  subprogram  2  also  requires  adoption  of  a  public  sector  debt 
management strategy and fiscal responsibility legislation, through an amendment to the existing 
Financial Management Act, 1990. 
 
15.  The government does not have a medium-term debt management strategy, and it has 
recognized that it needs to adopt a more comprehensive and integrated approach to ensure that 
debt  is  maintained  at  sustainable  levels.  The  debt  management  strategy  will  provide  the 
government with a path to restore debt sustainability, define its debt management objectives, 
set risk management strategies, and reduce the future financial burden of meeting its debt 
obligations. The existing Financial Management Act defines the general principles of managing 
government finances but does not contain provisions for debt management. The amendment to 
the act will therefore incorporate key components of the debt management policy. 
 
16.  The budget targets set under subprogram 1, and implemented under subprogram 2, are 
to be achieved through the actions of outputs 2 and 3, which are designed to restrain recurrent 
expenditure and increase tax revenue. The medium-term direction underlying the program is an 
increase  in  the  budget  surplus  to  5%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  by  FY2016,  as 
recommended by the IMF (footnote 6). 
 
17.  Output 2: Cabinet enforces restraint on recurrent expenditure. Under subprogram 1, 
the CAP Advisory Group prepared an independent review of public expenditure. The cabinet 
endorsed the CAP Advisory Group report and the actions recommended by the group to restrain 
recurrent expenditure. These included removing funding for 50 vacant positions in the civil 
service;  reducing  compensation  paid  to  landowners  for  MEC’s  access  to  their  land;  and 
reducing the government's administrative expenditure on housing leases and rentals, electricity, 
water, communications, vehicles, fuel, and professional services. In addition, a freeze on the 
government’s wage and salary bill, compensation paid to members of the Parliament (Nitijela), 
and housing allowances for public officials, was recommended by the CAP Advisory Group.

5 
Subprogram 1 also supported workforce audits in three major ministries—education, health, and 
public works—to guide efforts to raise the productivity of the civil service.11 
 
18.  Under subprogram 2, these expenditure targets were to be met through the FY2011 and 
FY2012  budgets.  The  government  made  general  across-the-board  cuts  to  expenditure  in 
FY2010 (5.0%), FY2011 (5.5%), and FY2012 (budgeted expenditure maintained at FY2011 
levels), rather than adopting the targeted cuts as originally envisaged by the Advisory Group; 
however,  this  approach  resulted  in  the  majority  of  targets  being  met.  Subprogram 2  also 
extends the workforce audits to five more ministries and agencies—finance, foreign affairs, 
internal  affairs,  attorney-general’s  office,  and  resources  and  development—as  well  as  the 
Nitijela, and begins actions to implement the findings in conjunction with the Public Service 
Commission. 
 
19.  Output  3:  Ministry  of  Finance  increases  tax  revenue.  Under  subprogram 1, the 
TRAM  Commission  completed  an  independent  assessment  of  the  tax  system  and 
recommended actions to increase tax revenue. The cabinet endorsed both the report and the 
recommendations. 
 
20.  Subprogram 2 requires implementation of the tax reforms as recommended by the 
TRAM Commission. The commission recommended replacing an array of existing taxes with a 
modern  tax  regime  that  has  higher  revenue  potential.  The  proposed  new  taxes  are  a 
consumption tax, an excise tax for certain goods (such as alcohol and fuel), a net profit tax for 
large businesses, and a modified wages and salaries tax. These will replace hotel taxes, import 
duties, various local taxes, and gross revenue taxes (except those on small businesses). The 
new taxes are designed to reduce distortions facing producers and consumers. The commission 
also recommended changes to the income tax by removing exemptions and adopting a tax-free 
threshold to reduce its regressive aspects, and to improve tax administration by unifying tax 
administration, strengthening tax audits, and harmonizing tax collection processes. 
 
21.  The Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre has been providing support to the 
government in this area. Under subprogram 2, legislation was introduced into Parliament in 
September 2012. The Australian Agency for International Development has recruited an advisor 
for MOF (Division of Customs, Treasury, Revenue and Taxation) to successfully implement the 
reforms over a 2-year period. Actions under way to improve tax administration focus on tax-filing 
assistance and tax payment, audit and investigations, objections and appeals, management of 
delinquent taxpayers, and considering more efficient information technology systems. The level 
of  taxpayer  noncompliance  is  high,  and  relatively  simple  efforts  to  improve  tax  filing  and 
payment should yield solid revenue gains.12 
 
22.  Raising compliance through more rigorous tax administration is expected to generate 
most of the additional tax revenue targeted under the program, as the new taxes should be 
largely revenue-neutral for existing taxpayers in the short-term. The medium-term target is to lift 
the ratio of taxes to GDP to 16.2% in FY2015, from 14.3% in FY2011, as the IMF recommended. 
 
23.  Output  4:  Selected  state-owned  enterprises  improve  their  performance.  Under 
subprogram 1, an assessment was conducted of the performance of the 11 major SOEs, and

the  cabinet  endorsed  good  practice  principles  to  guide  the  ongoing  SOE  reform. 13  A 
comprehensive recovery plan was prepared for MEC and endorsed by the MEC board, and 
implementation commenced. The cabinet and the MEC board endorsed debt restructuring for 
MEC, and the MEC board endorsed the establishment of a maintenance account to hold funds 
set aside for maintenance. 
 
24.  Subprogram 2 provides for annual public reporting on SOE performance, the adoption of 
an SOE policy, the introduction of an SOE act in Parliament, the continued implementation of 
the MEC comprehensive recovery plan, and the implementation of MEC's debt restructuring and 
maintenance account. Time-bound recovery plans, based on the application of good practice 
principles, have been prepared under subprogram 2 for other SOEs. 
 
25.  The SOE policy confirms the government’s commitment to 10 good practice principles 
for the management and operation of SOEs, adopted under subprogram 1, and covers the role 
of the responsible minister, the principle objective for the operation of SOEs, community service 
obligations, governance, and accountability requirements. The key components of the policy will 
be incorporated into an SOE act. Also under subprogram 2, strategic reform plans have been 
prepared for the Majuro Water and Sewer Company, Marshall Islands Shipping Corporation, 
and Tobolar Copra Processing Authority, and action is under way to implement the plans.14 
 
26.  The  MEC  comprehensive  recovery  plan  includes  actions  to  (i)  improve  corporate 
governance  through  reconstitution  of  the  board,  (ii)  improve  procurement  and  financial 
management, (iii) align tariffs to reflect costs, (iv) reduce system losses, (v) improve billing 
through prepaid metering and more rigorous collection, (vi) raise the efficiency of fuel usage, 
(vii) reduce nonessential expenditure, and (viii) overhaul the main generators and other major 
equipment (footnote 8). MEC's debt restructuring has three elements: (i) replacing a sovereign-
guaranteed  loan  from  the  Bank  of  Guam  with  a  concessional  loan  from  the  government, 
(ii) deferring principal repayments on an existing loan from the Rural Utilities Service of the US 
Department of Agriculture, and (iii) establishing a debt-servicing sinking fund. 
 
27.  Output  5:  Cabinet  ensures  effective  stakeholder  participation  in  public  sector 
reforms. A consultation and participation program was started under subprogram 1, and has 
been ongoing under subprogram 2. Project preparatory TA under subprogram 1 assisted the 
government  in  carrying  out  public  consultation,  bringing  together  stakeholders  from  the 
government, civil society organizations, academia, the private sector, and youth groups in six 
sessions.15 Open debate on a wide range of issues yielded significant information, opinions, 
insights, ideas, and recommendations. All consultations were bilingual. Each session covered 
the economy, fiscal and economic trends and outlook, and policy options and actions. A strong 
consensus emerged on key points related to ongoing economic difficulties, the necessity of 
adopting serious reforms to deal with imbalances, and the imperative that the cabinet take the 
lead in this reform process. 
 
28.  Under  subprogram  2,  the  government  has  sought  to  strengthen  engagement  with 
development partners to support its reform program. In December 2010, the government held

29.  Stakeholder  consultation  has  been  ongoing  since  the  approval  of  subprogram  1, 
particularly around tax and SOE reform. In March 2012, ADB also approved TA with a provision 
to support a second development partners’ meeting, once scheduled by the government.17 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
30.  The government has requested a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR3,242,000 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the program. The loan will have a 24-year 
term, including a grace period of 8 years; an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace 
period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; and such other terms and conditions as are set forth in 
the draft loan agreement. 
 
31.  The  loan  size  was  determined  after  consideration  of  (i)  the  government’s  FY2013 
financing needs, including the required contribution to the Compact trust fund that is intended to 
generate a revenue stream to replace Compact grants in FY2024; (ii) the significance and 
complexity  of  the  policy  actions  of  the  program,  and  the  budgetary  resources  required  to 
implement the program successfully; (iii) the conformity of the program with ADB’s COBP for the 
RMI;  and  (iv)  direct  budget  support  being  provided  by  other  development  partners.  The 
determination  of  the  loan  size  also  took  into  account  the  government’s  demonstrated 
commitment  to  implementing  the  program,  as  evidenced  by  the  development  policy  letter 
(Appendix 3). 
 
32.  The proposed loan size is within the established lending allocation, and is included in 
ADB’s COBP for the RMI.18 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
33.  MOF will be the executing agency and will be responsible for (i) overseeing all policy, 
legal, and regulatory actions to be undertaken in connection with the program; and (ii) ensuring 
that all policy reforms set out in the policy matrix are duly carried out in a timely manner 
(Appendix 4). MOF will also be responsible for program administration, disbursements, and 
maintenance of all program records. The public sector program period began on 25 August 
2009  and  all  subprogram  2  policy  actions  were  met  by  5  October  2012.19 Post-program

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
35.  The  primary  gain  from  the  program  in  the  medium  term  will  be  improved  fiscal 
sustainability of the government, as measured by the Compact trust fund being on track to 
replace Compact grants when they expire in FY2024. The IMF assessment letter is accessible 
from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Governance 
36.  The government’s ability to implement its budget as approved is integral to the success 
of the program. The general quality and comprehensiveness of the RMI budget has improved 
since 2009, with the incorporation of previously off-budget allocations into the main allocation 
process. The budget planning and approval process has also improved, and the FY2011 and 
FY2012 budgets were being prepared largely in accordance with the set calendar and budget 
schedule, in part due to support from ADB. 
 
37.  Government procurement is undertaken in accordance with the Procurement Code (Act), 
1988 and applies to expenditure of public funds irrespective of their source by the government. 
The code (i) aims to boost public confidence in the procedures followed in public procurement; 
(ii) ensures the fair and equitable treatment of all persons who deal with the  procurement 
system  of  the  government;  and  (iii) applies  greater  economy  to  government  procurement 
activities, and maximizes the purchasing value of public funds of the government. Procurement 
risks under the program are considered low. 
 
38.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  MOF.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its 
agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the program. 
To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the 
loan agreement. These measures will complement the actions under way to improve financial 
accountability and anticorruption measures, which are being put in place by the government 
with the support of its development partners.

C.  Poverty and Social 
39.  The program will contribute to poverty reduction in several ways. First, better fiscal 
management will reduce fiscal deficits; improve the capacity to deal with external shocks; and 
create a foundation for sustainable, equitable, and inclusive pro-poor economic growth. Second, 
revenue enhancement will enable the government to make transfers to the Compact trust fund, 
allowing a smooth transition to the post-Compact era, which could otherwise create social and 
economic tension as public expenditure and employment shrink and as poverty and deprivation 
worsen. Third, improving the efficiency of SOEs, especially MEC, will reduce the burden that 
cash transfers place on the budget, and make additional resources available for development.22 
 
D.  Safeguards 
40.  The  subprogram  is  classified  as  category  C  for  environment,  resettlement,  and 
indigenous  people.  No significant  adverse  environmental  impacts  have  been  identified.  No 
involuntary resettlement or impact on indigenous people is expected. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
41.  The potential benefits from undertaking fiscal and structural reforms to improve the long-
term fiscal sustainability of the RMI government are considered to outweigh the risks. Indeed, 
the cost of inaction could be substantial—a continued low growth rate, with implications for the 
government’s ability to fund basic social services and transition to the post-Compact era. Major 
risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 3 and detailed in the risk assessment 
and risk management plan.23

IV.  ASSURANCES 
42.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the loan 
documents. 
 
43.  The loan will become effective only after the government has satisfactorily fulfilled all 
policy actions for the release of the single tranche of subprogram 2. All policy actions set out in 
the policy matrix have been met. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
44.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB,  I recommend that the 
Board approve the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR3,242,000 to the Republic of the 
Marshall Islands for subprogram 2 of the Public Sector Program, from ADB’s Special Funds 
resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 
1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such 
other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft 
loan agreement presented to the Board.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency unit of the Republic of the Marshall Islands is the US dollar. 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADF  –  Asian Development Fund 
  CAP  –  Comprehensive Adjustment Program 
  COBP  –  country operations business plan 
  GDP  –  gross domestic product 
  IMF  –  International Monetary Fund 
  MEC  –  Marshalls Energy Company 
  MOF  –  Ministry of Finance 
  RMI  –  Republic of the Marshall Islands 
  SOE  –  state-owned enterprise 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TRAM  –  Tax and Revenue Reform and Modernization 
  US  –  United States 
 
 
NOTES 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of the Marshall Islands and its agencies 
ends on 30 September. ―FY‖ before a calendar year denotes the year in which 
the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2012 ends on 30 September 2012. 
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
